articles.headline: Pandemic Luxury: ‘Concierge-Style’ Coaches and $350 Movie Tickets
articles.snippet: The coronavirus is turning everyday pleasures into extravagances available only to those willing to shell out big bucks.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus is turning everyday pleasures into extravagances available only to those willing to shell out big bucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the bedroom of her East Village apartment, Alison Mazur relaxed into her chair and sighed contentedly while an aesthetician coated her nails in taupe polish. It was the first professional manicure-pedicure she’d had in four months, since coronavirus restrictions forced salons across the country to close their doors.

articles.headline: End of $600 Unemployment Bonus Could Push Millions Past the Brink
articles.snippet: A weekly supplement has helped the jobless to pay their bills and cushioned the economy. As it expires, Congress will determine what comes next.
articles.abstract: A weekly supplement has helped the jobless to pay their bills and cushioned the economy. As it expires, Congress will determine what comes next.
articles.lead_paragraph: When millions of Americans began losing their jobs in March, the federal government stepped in with a life preserver: $600 a week in extra unemployment benefits to allow workers to pay rent and buy groceries, and to cushion the economy.

articles.headline: Trump’s Request of an Ambassador: Get the British Open for Me
articles.snippet: Woody Johnson, the N.F.L. owner, Trump donor and ambassador to Britain, was warned not to get involved in trying to move the tournament to a Trump resort in Scotland, but he raised the idea anyway — and he failed.
articles.abstract: Woody Johnson, the N.F.L. owner, Trump donor and ambassador to Britain, was warned not to get involved in trying to move the tournament to a Trump resort in Scotland, but he raised the idea anyway — and he failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The American ambassador to Britain, Robert Wood Johnson IV, told multiple colleagues in February 2018 that President Trump had asked him to see if the British government could help steer the world-famous and lucrative British Open golf tournament to the Trump Turnberry resort in Scotland, according to three people with knowledge of the episode.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Lara Jakes and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: As Trump Pushes Into Portland, His Campaign Ads Turn Darker
articles.snippet: The Trump campaign is spending millions on ads that promote a dark and exaggerated portrayal of Democratic-led cities, a tactic that reinforces his “law and order’’ campaign message.
articles.abstract: The Trump campaign is spending millions on ads that promote a dark and exaggerated portrayal of Democratic-led cities, a tactic that reinforces his “law and order’’ campaign message.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Nick Corasaniti and Annie Karni

articles.headline: The Pandemic Isn’t Bringing Back Factory Jobs, at Least Not Yet
articles.snippet: It’s a moment of reckoning for global supply chains. But that doesn’t mean companies are flocking back to the United States.
articles.abstract: It’s a moment of reckoning for global supply chains. But that doesn’t mean companies are flocking back to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For companies with supply chains that snake around the globe, the crises have just kept coming: First the prolonged and painful U.S.-China trade war, then a pandemic that snarled shipments, stalled international travel and shut factory doors.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: U.S. Orders China to Close Houston Consulate, Citing Efforts to Steal Trade Secrets
articles.snippet: The Trump administration accused Chinese citizens of stealing scientific research and told the country’s diplomats in Texas to leave. Beijing warned it would retaliate.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration accused Chinese citizens of stealing scientific research and told the country’s diplomats in Texas to leave. Beijing warned it would retaliate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has abruptly ordered China to close its consulate in Houston, accusing diplomats of aiding economic espionage and the attempted theft of scientific research as the Trump administration sharply escalates its moves against China.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Lara Jakes and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: U.S. Northeast, Pummeled in the Spring, Now Stands Out in Virus Control
articles.snippet: In just over two months, the Northeast has gone from the country’s worst coronavirus hot spot to its most controlled. “It’s acting like Europe,” one expert said.
articles.abstract: In just over two months, the Northeast has gone from the country’s worst coronavirus hot spot to its most controlled. “It’s acting like Europe,” one expert said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Last week, as Dr. Emily Wroe left her home in Boston and drove west to see her parents in Idaho, she watched as signs of the pandemic became fewer and farther between.

articles.headline: In Electric Car Market, It’s Tesla and a Jumbled Field of Also-Rans
articles.snippet: Most traditional carmakers are struggling to produce and market electric vehicles even as Tesla sells hundreds of thousands of its luxury models.
articles.abstract: Most traditional carmakers are struggling to produce and market electric vehicles even as Tesla sells hundreds of thousands of its luxury models.
articles.lead_paragraph: Although it has become the world’s most valuable automaker, Tesla still has to figure out how to become consistently profitable, reduce quality problems in its luxury cars and more quickly turn alluring prototypes into mass-produced vehicles.

articles.headline: Froth Returns to China’s Stock Market, Echoing the 2015 Crisis
articles.snippet: Chinese stocks are surging. Foreign investors have rushed in. University graduates and factory workers are opening up trading accounts. Is disaster on the horizon?
articles.abstract: Chinese stocks are surging. Foreign investors have rushed in. University graduates and factory workers are opening up trading accounts. Is disaster on the horizon?
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Beijing signaled this month that it was time to buy China, investors did not hesitate. But it did not take long for some to get cold feet as officials warned that the market was overheating.

articles.headline: Diane von Furstenberg’s Brand Is Left Exposed by the Pandemic
articles.snippet: The fashion designer’s potent personal profile obscured the fact that her company, DVF, had been losing money for years. The coronavirus crisis changed all that.
articles.abstract: The fashion designer’s potent personal profile obscured the fact that her company, DVF, had been losing money for years. The coronavirus crisis changed all that.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end of February, just as the coronavirus was beginning to cast its pall over Europe, an elite crowd that included the likes of Anna Wintour, Jeff Bezos and Seth Meyers gathered in the gilded 19th-century halls of the Ministry of Europe and Foreign Affairs in Paris to watch Diane von Furstenberg be awarded the Légion d’Honneur.
articles.byline: By Vanessa Friedman and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Pfizer Gets $1.95 Billion to Produce Coronavirus Vaccine by Year’s End
articles.snippet: Two pharmaceutical companies announced a nearly $2 billion contract for 600 million doses of a vaccine, with the first 100 million promised before the end of the year.
articles.abstract: Two pharmaceutical companies announced a nearly $2 billion contract for 600 million doses of a vaccine, with the first 100 million promised before the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Here’s what you need to know about Pfizer’s Covid-19 Vaccine.]
articles.byline: By Noah Weiland, Denise Grady and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Hearst Employees Say Magazine Boss Led Toxic Culture
articles.snippet: At Cosmopolitan staff meetings, workers complain of discrimination and tokenism. Former employees say the Hearst Magazines president, Troy Young, made sexually offensive remarks.
articles.abstract: At Cosmopolitan staff meetings, workers complain of discrimination and tokenism. Former employees say the Hearst Magazines president, Troy Young, made sexually offensive remarks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update: Troy Young has resigned, the chief executive of Hearst told employees.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson and Ben Smith

articles.headline: The Amazon Critic Who Saw Its Power From the Inside
articles.snippet: Tim Bray was a celebrated engineer at Amazon. Now, he is its highest-profile defector.
articles.abstract: Tim Bray was a celebrated engineer at Amazon. Now, he is its highest-profile defector.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Tim Bray, an internet pioneer and a former vice president at Amazon, sent shock waves through the tech giant in early May when he resigned for what he called “a vein of toxicity” running through its culture.

articles.headline: For Palestinian Police, Much to Lose if Israel Annexes West Bank Land
articles.snippet: Palestinian security officers, scorned for working with Israel, say they are on the front lines of building a state. But what if the state-building project fizzles?
articles.abstract: Palestinian security officers, scorned for working with Israel, say they are on the front lines of building a state. But what if the state-building project fizzles?
articles.lead_paragraph: JENIN, West Bank — What wounded Maj. Zahi Jamhour most, he said, wasn’t that the Palestinians he had sworn to protect threw stones at him. It wasn’t even the bullet shot through his leg by an Israeli soldier — a mistake, he was told later — after his Palestinian police squad had risked their lives to rescue a Jew from an attempted lynching.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger, Adam Rasgon and Mohammed Najib
